passages.text: Daily Valuation Sheet | Banks Analyser & Global Banks and Fintech Valuation Weekly sheet
RBC's Record Quarter for Capital Markets Fuels Earnings Beat
Investment Companies Daily: FGEN/FSFL BESS asset update, RSE interim results and EGM result
Christopher Brown (44- 20) 7134- 4722

Foreigner Solar Fund (FSFL, Neutral) & Foresight Environmental Infrastructure (FGEN, Neutral) - BESS asset update - FSFL and FGEN both jointly own, on a 50/50 basis, several battery energy storage system (BESS) assets. Today both FSFL and FGEN have announced that they have exchanged contracts for the sale of their stakes in Lunanhead, a 50MW BESS asset located in Perthshire, Scotland, at a price that is in line with the 30/6/25 carrying value and completion of the deal is due later this quarter. FGEN says the Lunanhead sale represents less than 0.2% of its total portfolio value. Both FSFL and FGEN say their investment managers are exploring options for Clayfords, another 50MW BESS asset jointly owned. Both FSFL and FGEN also say that a third BESS asset, Sandridge BESS, a 50MW battery storage project in Wiltshire that the two funds jointly own, has been energised and the site will now begin final commissioning and testing, with commercial operations due shortly thereafter. FSFL and FGEN each say that their boards and managers have been considering developing the BESS asset sold against alternative capital uses, including developing the asset or using capital for buybacks or debt repayment and decided the sale was the best option.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
Yuri R Fernandes (1- 212) 622- 3400

Brazil's Central Bank published credit data for July with negative data for agro and Banco do Brasil - 90- days NPL was up \(+75\) bps M- o- M and early 15- 90 days NPL worsened \(\sim 40\) bps M- o- M (driven by earmarked rates). As for the system, we have a mixed first take: (1) loan growth remained stable at \(10.7\%\) Y- o- Y, although we note some marginal acceleration from foreign players (e.g. Santander) at \(0.5\%\) M- o- M; (2) NPLs rose 20bps M- o- M to \(3.8\%\) (while accounting changes may still distort the numbers we believe July is a more normalized data) - worsening was led by public banks (+30bps), while private and foreign banks were less pronounced (+10bps); (3) spreads were down 20bps M- o- M or 10bps for non- directed loans. Other interesting takes include:
Yuri R Fernandes (1- 212) 622- 3400

Today we hosted a call with Juan Toro, Grupo Sura's CFO, one of the largest financial companies in Colombia with significant presence in LatAm. In addition to owning \(46\%\) of Cibest/Bancomlobia voting shares (or \(\sim 25\%\) economic stake), the company owns an insurance division, investments and pension. In today's call, management emphasized the group's efforts to sustain profitability and having room to drive ROE towards \(13 - 15\%\) levels (from low teens today) through efficiency gains, portfolio optimization, and disciplined leverage reduction, while also highlighting opportunities in asset management, insurance, and regional partnerships - we tend to see Sura as strategic for Cibest/Bancomlobia. We also discussed capital, new corporate structure, among other topics.
Andrew Triggs (61- 2) 9003- 8919

BOQ provided a multi- faceted release to the market which: 1) flagged the removal of FY26 targets for \(8\%\) ROE and \(56\%\) cost/income ratio; 2) provided a trading update with no detail (\$375m to \$385m cash NPAT for FY25, vs consensus \$374m); 3) flagged the potential for a whole- of- loan sale for part of the equipment finance portfolio (no details provided, or certainty on a transaction proceeding); 4) flagged further below- the- line charges for 2H25; 5) flagged a partnership with Capgemini to lower cost to serve. Unfortunately, the trading update provides insight into how much of the better profit performance relates to lower credit costs of operational performance. A capital- efficient transaction had previously been discussed by the company, but there is no detail and such a transaction is unusual for a bank that is not growing quickly and does not have a strong distribution capability.
Haomin Chen (86- 21) 6106 6347

2Q results: Incremental messages are mixed. BoHZ had pre- announced strong 2Q profits growth of \(+16\%\) y/y in Jul- 25 (link); we believe the full report delivered mixed messages. On the positive side: 1) 2Q PPOP \((+7\%)\) y/y beat JPMe by \(13\%\) , supported by NII \((+12\%)\) y/y) and lower opex \((+3\%)\) y/y); and 2) CB conversion into equities in 2Q led to improvements in the capital position. On the negative side: 1) we haven't observed signs of easing NIM pressure. 1H25 NIM contracted by 5bps h/h, the magnitude of which is larger vs. 2H24; 2) although overall asset quality metrics remain stable, we note rising AQ risks in the retail segment.

Retail NPL \(\%\) increased by 25bps h/h in 1H25. In addition, we expect short- term share price pressure from China Life's share reduction in HZ (announced on July 15). We maintain our Neutral rating.
Harsh Wardhan Modi (65) 6882- 2450

HLBK announced 4Q FY25 profit of M\\$1.09bn, up \(5\%\) y/y, \(15\%\) q/q and \(6\%\) above JPME. On a full- year basis, core profit of M\\$4.7bn was up \(12\%\) y/y (reported at M\\$4.3bn, up \(2\%\) y/y, due to a BOCD dilution- related exceptional item of M\\$408mn). The bank's NIM was up 3bps q/q to \(1.90\%\) , outperforming trends at peers. Loan and deposit growth was quite firm at \(8\%\) y/y, with costs coming in lower. Fees and treasury were a touch weaker, but not enough to offset overall revenue growth of \(10\%\) y/y. It may be possible that the bank is looking to lock in higher- duration securities portfolio in a bid to sustain NIMs in a lower- yield environment going forward. Hence, investment income is lower now, but will show up in NII over time. AQ was pristine, with a bp of credit cost this quarter, leading to 186bps q/q increase in coverage to \(97\%\) . On a pre- BCOD basis, pre- tax earnings were up \(21\%\) y/y, with a \(2\%\) beat for full year ( \(\sim 7\%\) beat to Street estimates). This is probably one of the best domestic bank performances in the sector this quarter. BOCD had firm results as well, with contributions up \(13\%\) q/q to M\\$367mn, or \(27\%\) of group pre- tax. We stay Ow on Hong Leong Bank.
Katherine Lei (852) 2800- 8552

2Q25 results - in line. 2Q profit increased \(4\%\) y/y and was in line with JPME. On the positive side, revenue and PPoP were ahead of expectation driven by strong non- fee income and improved operating efficiency. Fee income growth also recovered to \(6\%\) y/y, and asset quality remained stable in the quarter. On the negative side, NIM contracted by 4bps q/q, worse than joint- stock banks' NIM trend (- 1bp q/q) indicated by NFRA data. Note that Citic announced an interim dividend at \(29\%\) payout ratio on 1H25 net profits, up from \(28\%\) in 1H24. We remain Overweight.
Katherine Lei (852) 2800- 8552

We raised Futu's EPS forecasts post a strong 2Q25 print (link), and in this note, we increase the valuation multiple and raise our PT by \(35\%\) to US\\$270, implying 28x 2026E PE. The key drivers for this re- rating are as follows: First, there is a strong correlation between the growth outlook and PE multiple. Futu has demonstrated significant growth in clients, AUM, revenue, and profits since 2024, yet the multiple re- rating has lagged (current 26E PE of 20x vs historical FY1 mean of 23x). Second, we believe strong client acquisition in HK/SG/MY, rise in wallet share per client and digital assets development will further drive growth momentum. Third, Futu is trading at a steep discount to peers (Hood, IBKR & EM), despite a better growth outlook. With an easing of the regulatory overhang, we expect the discount to narrow. We remain OW.

Royal Bank of Canada topped estimates on strong performance across its biggest businesses and as the firm set aside less money than expected to cover possible loan losses, a rebound from notable misses on credit earlier this year. The company's shares surged.

Canada's largest bank earned C\\$3.84 per share on an adjusted basis in its fiscal third quarter, according to a statement Wednesday, topping the C\\$3.25 average estimate of analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Provisions for credit losses totaled C\\$881 million (\\(636 million) for the three months through July, less than the C\\$1.1 billion analysts had forecast.
The bank's overall return on equity came in at \(17.7\%\) on an adjusted basis, easily outpacing

the medium- term target of \(16\%\) or better the bank set at its investor day in March. Chief Executive Officer Dave McKay told analysts that he and his management team would review their expectations on that front and share them in the fourth quarter.

"The only thing that's holding us back from sitting down and reaffirming and updating guidance is our uncertainty around the tariff scenario right now," he said on a conference call. McKay added several caveats about the macroeconomic and geopolitical risks that still loom, pointing to crucial renegotiations of the US- Canada- Mexico Agreement and trade uncertainty more broadly, but struck an optimistic tone on balance, citing resilience among Royal Bank's more- affluent clients and its ability to win a disproportionate share of the market across business lines.
"Give us a little bit of time to read the environment, but we feel very good about our results," he said.

Royal Bank posted record revenue of \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}3.76\) billion in its capital- markets division, up \(25\%\) from a year earlier. Expenses at the business climbed \(17\%\) , largely due to higher variable compensation as its bankers took home more pay on elevated activity across fixed- income trading, lending, dealmaking and more.

Net income at the unit, which includes significant US operations and is the largest capital- markets franchise among Canadian banks, totaled \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}1.33\) billion for the quarter, higher than the \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}1.1\) billion average forecast of four analysts in a Bloomberg survey.

The company also has a bigger wealth- management operation relative to its Canadian peers and has seen an appreciation in assets under management as markets surged in recent months. The division saw net income of \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}1.1\) billion, beating the \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}964\) million average forecast of four analysts.

Royal Bank shares climbed \(6\%\) to \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}201.71\) at 12:02 p.m. in Toronto, after gaining as much as \(7.5\%\) at the start of trading, notching their biggest intraday increase in more than five years and hitting a record.

City National Bank, Royal Bank's Los Angeles- based subsidiary, saw a surge in profit, with net income more than doubling from a year earlier to \(\mathbb{S}114\) million. The business, which is included in Royal Bank's wealth- management results, has reported better margins as it works through a turnaround after facing profitability challenges and a balance sheet bailout two years ago.

On credit, Royal Bank surprised markets last quarter by taking the most conservative approach of its peers and preparing for tariff- fueled economic uncertainty by setting aside significant provisions on loans that are still in good standing. And, earlier in the year, the firm's credit performance was dented by one large account in its capital- markets division. After its cautious bent last quarter, Royal Bank is now more optimistic, saying Wednesday that "favorable changes to our macroeconomic forecast" spurred it to release \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{S}28\) million in provisions on performing loans. The bank noted that while it has seen some deterioration of credit quality, "fiscal support is expected to provide further lift to the Canadian economy." Chief Risk Officer Graeme Hepworth said headwinds remain going into next year, but suggested that credit concerns are already starting to plateau.

"Everyone's always interested in when we're going to see the peak of the credit cycle," he said, adding that while there won't be one "singular magical quarter" when the credit cycle peaks, "we're kind of in that range now and we would expect to persist in that range."

The release of provisions on performing loans "could help alleviate recent concerns around the bank's PCL trajectory following last quarter's larger reserve built relative to peers," Bank of Nova Scotia analyst Mike Rizvanovic said in a note to clients.

In recent quarters, Royal Bank has also gained market share in Canadian commercial loans and deposits while keeping costs low and identifying savings through its acquisition of HSBC Holdings Plc's Canadian assets last year. (Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.)

For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

Research excerpts: This material may include excerpts from previously published reports. For access to the full reports, including analyst certification and important disclosures, please contact your sales representative or the covering analyst's team, or visit https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
